name: Dummy Deck
description: Sandbox for testing new technical phrases before migration.

cards.sideA: Son solo importaciones y dependencias.

sideB.text: They are just imports and dependencies.
It's just imports and dependencies.
These are merely imports and dependencies.

cards.note: ~importacions~ is not an English word; the correct term is [imports].

cards.sideA: La importacion tiene dependencias.

sideB.text: The import has dependencies.
This import comes with dependencies.
The import implies dependencies.

cards.sideA: Es la dependencia de una importacion.

sideB.text: It's a dependency of an import.
It is an import dependency.
That's a dependency belonging to an import.
It's the dependency of an import.

cards.note: ~It's a dependency of an importacion~ is incorrect because [import] is the correct English term.

cards.sideA: No estamos ocultándo el mensaje.

sideB.text: We aren't hiding the message.
We are not suppressing the message.
We're not concealing the message.

cards.note: In logging contexts, [suppressing] is a common term for preventing a message from appearing.

cards.sideA: La cantidad de productos por paquete es diferente.

sideB.text: The quantity per pack is different for each item.
Pack sizes vary from product to product.
The item count per package is not the same for all products.
The quantity of products per pack is different.

cards.note:
[Item count] is a precise technical term for quantity.

~The amount of products~ is incorrect because 'amount' is used for uncountable nouns; use [number] or [quantity] for countable items like products.

cards.sideA: Las unidades por paquete varían según el producto.

sideB.text: Units per pack vary depending on the product.
Units per package change based on the SKU.
Each product has a different number of units per pack.

cards.note:
[SKU] (Stock Keeping Unit) is the standard acronym for a specific product code.

~Unit per pack are different~ is incorrect; use [Units per pack are] to maintain [subject-verb agreement].

cards.sideA: Eso depende de la unidad de medida del producto.

sideB.text: That depends on the product's unit of measure.
It is based on the product's UOM.
That is determined by the specific unit of measure for each item.
That depends on the unit of measure of the product.

cards.note: [UOM] is the standard acronym for Unit of Measure.

cards.sideA: Estamos invirtiendo el signo.

sideB.text: We are flipping the sign.
We are inverting the sign.
We're reversing the sign.

cards.note: In programming, [flip] is very common for boolean toggles or sign reversals (+/-).

cards.sideA: Es necesario invertir el signo en esa condicion.

sideB.text: It's necessary to flip the sign in that condition.
We need to invert the sign in that condition.
The sign must be reversed in that condition.

cards.sideA: Apuesto que en el futuro sera asi.

sideB.text: I bet it'll be like that in the future.
I bet in the future it will be like this.
I'm sure it's going to be that way in the future.

cards.note:
[I bet] is an informal but standard way to express strong confidence in a prediction.

~I bet on the future it will be like this~ is less natural; use [in the future] to describe when something will happen.

cards.sideA: Pero continuo no teniendo esa opción.

sideB.text: But I still don't have that option.
I still lack that option, though.
However, I continue to not have that option.

cards.note:
**[184]**

[Still don't have] is the most natural translation for 'continuo no teniendo'.

~But I'm still not having~ is incorrect because 'have' is a [state verb] and is rarely used in continuous forms. ~But I continue not having~ is grammatically possible but [less natural] than 'I still don't have'.

cards.sideA: Descarta los valores nulos.

sideB.text: Filter out null values.
Discard null values.
Exclude null values.

cards.note: [Filter out] explicitly means to remove unwanted items. [Filter] alone can sometimes be ambiguous (keep vs remove).

cards.sideA: Filtra el ruido de los datos.

sideB.text: Filter out the data noise.
Filter out the noise from the data.
Remove the noise from the data.
Filter out the noise of the data.

cards.sideA: Excluye los correos duplicados.

sideB.text: Filter out duplicate emails.
Exclude duplicate emails.
Remove duplicate emails.

cards.note: ~It excludes duplicate emails~ changes the command into a [statement].

cards.sideA: Filtra los resultados viejos.

sideB.text: Filter out old results.
Filter out outdated results.
Exclude the old results.

cards.note:
[Outdated] refers to data that is no longer valid or relevant.

~It filters out old results~ and ~It filters old results~ change the [imperative] mood of the original sentence to a statement.

cards.sideA: El flujo de datos se interrumpió durante la actualización.

sideB.text: The data stream was interrupted during the update.
The flow of data stopped during the update.
The data stream got cut off during the update.
The data stream got interrupted during the update.

cards.note: [Stream] is the technical term for a continuous flow of data.

cards.sideA: Debemos procesar este flujo de información de forma secuencial.

sideB.text: We must process this information stream sequentially.
We need to process this data flow sequentially.
This info stream has to be processed in sequence.

cards.note: ~in a sequel way~ is incorrect; [sequentially] or [in sequence] are the correct terms for this context.

cards.sideA: El servidor no soporta una transmisión de audio tan pesada.

sideB.text: The server does not support such a heavy audio stream.
The server can't handle such a heavy audio stream.
The server doesn't support that heavy of an audio stream.

cards.note: ~The server does not support an audio stream so heavy~ is incorrect; use the [such a + adjective + noun] structure or place the adjective before the noun.

cards.sideA: ¿A quien se lo dijiste?

sideB.text: Who did you tell?
Who did you say that to?
To whom did you say it?

cards.note: [To whom] is very formal. [Who did you tell] is the standard daily/professional form.

cards.sideA: ¿Quién fue?

sideB.text: Who was it?
Who did it?
Who was the one?

cards.note: When asking about an action (who caused the bug?), [Who did it?] is usually the intended meaning.

cards.sideA: ¿Quién te lo dijo?

sideB.text: Who told you?
Who told you that?
Who said that to you?

cards.sideA: Probablemente fue un cambio indirecto.

sideB.text: It was probably an indirect change.
It was likely an indirect change.
That was probably a side effect.

cards.sideA: No lo hare hoy, pero sí mañana.

sideB.text: I won't do it today, but I will tomorrow.
I'm not doing it today, but I definitely will tomorrow.
I won't do it today; however, I will tomorrow.

cards.sideA: No esta llegando el dato aun.

sideB.text: The data isn't arriving yet.
The data hasn't arrived yet.
We're not receiving the data yet.
The data isn't coming yet.

cards.sideA: ¿Ya ha llegado el dato?

sideB.text: Has the data arrived yet?
Did the data come in yet?
Is the data here yet?

cards.note: ~Has the data came in yet?~ is incorrect because the [past participle] of 'come' is 'come', not 'came'.

cards.sideA: El dato ya ha llegado!

sideB.text: The data has arrived!
The data is here!
The data has just come in!

cards.note: Using [arrive] for data is correct and common in technical contexts to describe information reaching a destination.

cards.sideA: El servidor está teniendo una nueva dirección IP.

sideB.text: The server has a new IP address.
The server now has a different IP.
A new IP address belongs to the server.

cards.note:
**[184]**

~The server is having~ is a logic error. Ownership of an attribute is a [state], not an action.

~The server has a new IP direction~ is incorrect because [address] is the technical term for a network location, whereas 'direction' refers to an orientation or heading.

cards.sideA: El sistema está teniendo muchos errores de validación.

sideB.text: The system has many validation errors.
There are many validation errors in the system.
The system contains several validation errors.
The system has a lot of validation errors.

cards.note:
**[184]**

Avoid ~is having errors~ when describing a current state. Use [has] to denote the presence of these items in the system.

cards.sideA: Como el servidor falló, perdimos los logs.

sideB.text: Since the server failed, we lost the logs.
Since there was a server failure, the logs were lost.
Because the server crashed, the log data is gone.
As the server failed, we lost the logs.

cards.note:
**[186]**

[Since] here functions as a [conjunction of cause], providing the reason for the data loss.

~Like the server failed~ is incorrect because [like] is used for similarity or comparison, whereas [as] or [since] are required to express a cause or reason.

cards.sideA: Como ya terminaste, puedes revisar mi PR.

sideB.text: Since you've already finished, you can review my PR.
Since you are done, you can check my pull request.
Now that you are finished, feel free to review my code.
Since you finished, you can review my PR.
As you've already finished, you can review my PR.

cards.note:
**[186]**

Using [since] to translate 'Como...' at the beginning of a sentence is very common in professional requests.

cards.sideA: Ya sea que elijamos React o Vue, el tiempo de entrega es el mismo.

sideB.text: Whether we choose React or Vue, the delivery time is the same.
Whether we pick React or Vue, the lead time remains identical.
The delivery time is the same, regardless of whether we choose React or Vue.

cards.note:
**[185]**

[Whether] is used to present two alternatives (React vs. Vue) where the outcome remains constant.

~Whether we choose React or Vue, the deadline is the same~ is not accurate here because [delivery time] (the duration of the work) is different from a [deadline] (a specific date/time limit).

cards.sideA: Ya sea que el servidor esté activo o no, la app debe funcionar offline.

sideB.text: Whether the server is active or not, the app must work offline.
Whether or not the server is up, the app should function offline.
The app needs to function offline, whether the server is online or offline.

cards.note:
**[185]**

The structure [Whether... or not] is the standard way to express 'Ya sea que... o no'.

cards.sideA: No hay necesidad de reiniciar el servidor ahora.

sideB.text: There is no need to restart the server now.
We don't have a need to reboot the server at the moment.
There's no requirement to restart the server right now.

cards.note:
**[187]**

~There is no need of restarting~ is a common error. Although 'of' is a preposition, the noun [need] implies a [requirement for a future action], so it must be followed by [to + infinitive].

cards.sideA: Esta es nuestra oportunidad de corregir el error.

sideB.text: This is our opportunity to fix the error.
We have an opportunity to correct the bug now.
This represents our opening to fix the mistake.

cards.note:
**[187]**

~Our opportunity of fixing~ is incorrect. The noun [opportunity] describes [potential], and follows the semantic pattern that requires the [to + infinitive] structure.

cards.sideA: El plan de actualizar la base de datos ha cambiado.

sideB.text: The plan to update the database has changed.
Our plan to upgrade the database is different now.
The roadmap to update the DB was modified.

cards.note:
**[187]**

~The plan of updating~ or ~for updating~ sounds unnatural. Since a [plan] is an [intention for future action], you must use [to + infinitive] regardless of the 'de' in Spanish.
